div.head: Synchronization in Random Weighted
div.p: Directed Networks Maurizio Porfiri, Daniel J. Stilwell, and Erik M. Bollt

Abstract-We assess synchronization of oscillators that are coupled via a time-varying stochastic network, modeled as a weighted directed random graph that switches at a given rate between a set of possible graphs. The existence of any graph edge is probabilistic and independent from the existence of any other edge. We further allow each edge to be weighted differently. Even if the network is always instantaneously not connected, we show that sufficient information is propagated through the network to allow almost sure local synchronization as long as the expected value of the network is connected, and that the switching rate is sufficiently fast. Index Terms-Ad hoc networking, directed graphs, fast switching, random graphs, synchronization, weighted graphs.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: S INCE Huygen's early observations of weakly coupled clock pendula [23], synchronization has been found in a wide variety of phenomena, especially in recent years, ranging from biological systems that include fire flies in the forest [8], [37], animal gates [11], descriptions of the heart [18], [22], [53], and improved understanding of brain seizures [39], to chemistry [27], nonlinear optics [41], and meteorology [13]. Many excellent reviews are now available, including [10], [17], [36], [38], [45], and [52].

Despite the very large literature to be found on synchronization, the great majority of research activities have been focused on static networks whose connectivity and coupling strengths are constant in time. For example, static networks are assumed for the analysis of [1], [4], [31], [43], and [44]. However, there are applications where the coupling strengths and even the network topology can evolve in time. Recent work such as [5], [6], [24], [32]- [34], [49], [51], [57], and [58] are among the few to consider time-dependent couplings. There is even less previous work concerning problems of stochastic time-varying couplings as we address in this paper, see, e.g., [7], [12], and [40].

For the case of static networks, extensive research activity has led to many well-established and broad criteria for oscillators synchronization, see, e.g., [9], [30], [43], and [44]. In [50], it is shown that if the time-varying network topology has a uniform time-average and switches at a sufficiently fast rate, then local synchronization is asymptotically achieved if the static time-average of the network topology asymptotically supports synchronization. In this case, the concept of fast switching enables the analysis of a time-varying network to be based on a static time-average of the network. In particular, the result applies to periodically switching network topologies.

The principal contribution of this paper is to extend the deterministic result of [50] to time-varying networks whose topology changes randomly over time. We formulate the synchronization problem over a random communication network, where each communication link has a different probability to exist and communication channels are arbitrary weighted. We show that if the average network asymptotically supports synchronization, then local synchronization is achieved asymptotically almost surely if the network topology switches at a sufficiently fast rate. This result is obtained by using a mixture of findings from stochastic stability theory [28], linear system theory [48], and fast switching theory [26]. Our results are limited to local synchronization of chaotic oscillators, even though global synchronization results have been developed for statically coupled oscillators [30].

Synchronization of linear dynamics in random communication networks have been studied for example in [21], [46], and [56]. In [21], consensus problem in undirected Erdös-Rényi network is studied. In [46], the findings of [21], are generalized to weighted directed networks. In [56], synchronization of linear oscillators in weighted directed networks is analyzed.

Our present paper is motivated by a variety of emerging applications, including cooperative control [16], [47], mathematical epidemiology [49], mobile ad hoc networks [35], and opinion dynamics [20]. In all of these cases, information is shared along agents via a time-varying network topology that may change randomly. In the context of mathematical epidemiology, our results relate to models of how disease propagates through large network of moving agents. Such a network would be time-varying since infections depend on proximity among infected and susceptible moving agents.

The paper is organized as follows. In Section II, we review the concept of random graph and we formally define the synchronization problem. In Section III, we derive some preliminary results on stochastic linear systems needed for proving our main claim which appears in Section IV. In Section V, our main result is illustrated by a numerical simulation for a network of Rössler oscillators. Section VI is left for conclusions.

div.head: IV. SYNCHRONIZATION THROUGH FAST-SWITCHING
div.p: Our principal result is to show that the network of coupled oscillators with stochastic time-varying can synchronize even if the network is insufficiently coupled to support synchronization at every instant of time. We show that synchronization is achieved as long as the average network , corresponding to the graph Laplacian in (1), supports synchronization and the switching period between new samples of the network topology is sufficiently small. In other words, analysis of synchronization for the stochastic time-varying network (2) reduces to analysis of synchronization for the static network (13) along with sufficiently fast switching of the network topology. The case of static networks has been extensively addressed in the literature, and analysis tools include the well-known master-stability function [43]. We note that the analysis herein requires that the transverse dynamics is uniformly asymptotically stable, which cannot be directly inferred using the master-stability function. This popular method can be used as a starting point and as an easily checkable surrogate to indicate if the transverse dynamics is stable. Alternatively, criteria based on direct demonstration of a Lyapunov function can be used to guarantee uniform asymptotic stability as done in [30].

A similar result for consensus problems under a random directed network has been presented in [46]. In [46], it is shown that if the average network supports consensus then consensus is achievable for the time-varying network as long as the graph topology changes sufficiently fast. Both this work and [46] use fast switching techniques to infer the behavior of the time-varying system from its time-average. The mathematical framework therein developed rather differs from the one presented here. In consensus problems, the dynamics of the individual oscillators are not considered. As a result, the consensus protocol is described in terms of a homogeneous Markov chain for which classical results from stochastic stability [28] are applicable. Also, the consensus problem on the average network is a linear time-invariant problem.

div.head: V. ILLUSTRATION
div.p: To illustrate fast switching concepts applied to synchronization of a set of oscillators coupled through a randomly switching graph, we consider a set of Rössler attractors where , , , , and . Oscillators are coupled through the variables via which changes randomly at the transition instants . Each edge is assigned the same probability to exists, and the same unitary weight. One may naturally ask if such a directed random graph is close to percolation, since it is closely related to the undirected Erdös-Rényi graph [15] for which the percolation question can be directly addressed. However, the percolation problem is not relevant here, since it is not necessary for our network to be instantaneously connected. Indeed, it is possible for the network to instantaneously consist of many subcomponents when the system is changed with a fast enough . We consider as example, a network of 25 oscillators, and we assume that switching occurs with a period . Figs. 1 and 2 depict the coordinate of the set of coupled Rössler oscillators using the average graph and the random graph respectively, versus the time . Fig. 3 reports the dynamics of the network topology for the first six time intervals.

We note that our results are limited to local synchronization despite the fact that presented numerical results seem to indicate that the stronger property of global synchronization might in fact be exhibited by the case-study system.

div.head: VI. CONCLUSION
div.p: New generalizations on synchronization of mutually coupled oscillators are presented. We pose the synchronization problem in a stochastic framework where communication among nodes is modeled as a weighted directed random switching graph. We utilize tools based on fast switching and stochastic stability, and show that local synchronization is asymptotically achieved if the average communication network asymptotically supports synchronization and if the network topology is changing with a sufficiently fast rate. A numerical simulation illustrates the theoretical achievements of the present paper.

figure.head: Maurizio
figure.figDesc: Porfiri was born in Rome, Italy, in 1976. He received the M.Sc. and Ph.D. degrees in engineering mechanics from the Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University (Virginia Tech), Blacksburg, in 2000 and 2006; the "Laurea" in electrical engineering (with honors) and the Ph.D. degree in theoretical and applied mechanics from the University of Rome "La Sapienza" and the University of Toulon (dual degree program), in 2001 and 2005, respectively. From 2005 to 2006, he held a Postdoctoral position with the Electrical and Computer Engineering Department, Virginia Tech. He is currently an Assistant Professor of mechanical engineering with the Polytechnic Institute of New York University, Brooklyn, NY. His research interests include dynamical systems theory, mathematical control theory, mechanics of advanced materials, MEMS, and underwater robotics. Dr. Porfiri is a recipient of the NSF CAREER award in 2008.

Daniel J. Stilwell received the B.S. degree is computer engineering from the University of Massachusetts, Amherst, in 1991, the M.S. degree in electrical engineering from the Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University (Virginia Tech), Blacksburg, in 1993, and the Ph.D. degree in electrical engineering from Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, MD, in 1999.

He is currently an Associate Professor with the Bradley Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Virginia Tech, where he teaches courses on controls and robotics. He conducts and supervises research in the areas of distributed estimation and decentralized control, environmental sampling, and the autonomous vehicle systems.

Dr. He has been a member of the Clarkson University Mathematics and Computer Science Faculty, together with the Physics Department, since 2002, where he is currently a full professor. His core research area has been in dynamical systems, including fundamental issues of topological dynamics, symbolic dynamics, measurable dynamics and transfer operators, as well as stochastic dynamical systems. Additionally, as an applied mathematician, he has worked with engineers and other scientists in problems involving control theory applications including air foil flutter suppression, information processing, image object detection, control of chaos, physiological data processing and modeling, as well as developing a deeper understanding of both dynamics of networks and dynamics on networks including applications in communications and social and epidemiological settings.
